issues.description: The problem statement says that each PersonController method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> as a parameter (references notes), but both the template and the solution use Consumer<List<Person>>. This is a clear mismatch in the method parameter type described in the exercise text vs. the actual code signatures. Students reading the text may be confused which type to use when implementing PersonController methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> for the PersonController methods (replace the erroneous 'Consumer<List<Note>>' with 'Consumer<List<Person>>') so it matches the template and solution method signatures and avoids student confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2) says: "Each method takes a `Consumer<List<Note>>` parameter" when referring to the PersonController methods that operate on persons. The template and solution controller code use `Consumer<List<Person>>` for these methods. This is a cross-artifact naming mismatch: the problem text refers to Note where it should refer to Person, which can confuse students about the expected parameter type for PersonController methods and the mapping between the textual requirements and the code skeleton.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the problem statement text to correctly reference the consumer type used by the PersonController methods. Replace `Consumer<List<Note>>` with `Consumer<List<Person>>` in the Part 2 description so the textual requirements and the code signatures consistently refer to the same conceptual entity (a consumer receiving the list of Person).
